thread.title: Looking a lot like Christmas

title: Looking a lot like Christmas
text:
Pitt Street shopping mall will soon be inundated with Christmas shoppers. Photo: Daniel Munoz
This weekend is considered a bonanza for retailers as avid fans from the Australian Football League (AFL) and the National Rugby League (NRL) snap up no end of football paraphernalia to support their teams in the finals.
And if the team is lucky enough to have a win, then the sales of premiership guernseys, scarfs, hats/beanies and the bigger ticket apparel items, among the inflatable fingers, all hit a high.
But once the cheering has ended, what next for the retailers?
Why, of course, Christmas.
Advertisement We all joke about seeing Easter eggs for sale in February and mince pies in October, but for a retailer, the changing seasons take on a whole new meaning.
And, in the current state of the sector, with fickle consumer sentiment, it's no laughing matter.
The housing boom is providing some joy as it is generating cash through home sales, which allows people to upgrade furnishings, renovate or use the excess cash on other items.
But for apparel retailers, it can be a lottery.
Given the smallness of the local population, compared with most other G7 countries, a lot of Australian apparel retailers are always left with excess stock at the end of each season.
Hence the extended periods of discounting that have plagued retailers for years – and frustrated shoppers: Nothing worse than seeing the jumper, already on sale one week, in the $2 bin the next.
That's the one trend that international brands are introducing to Australia – the six-week churn.
But with the heat wave Summer-like conditions currently hitting most of the country, retailers are once again, smiling.
Fashion retailers buy their Spring/Summer stock a year in advance and are now getting items out of storage and into the shops to cater for the rising demand in the lead-up to the Christmas festivities.
In the coming weeks there is also the Spring racing carnival, although well-seasoned attendees usually have outfits and millinery sorted well before the first Group 1 race meeting.
However, with the sun shining, late starters are heading to the stores for last minute fascinators, shoes and handbags.
The cash registers are ringing.
Amid this change of season activity, shop owners and landlords are also busy getting out the tinsel and Christmas trees in readiness for the festive season.
And that is only 11 shopping weeks away.
Already, the "mid season" sale stock is getting corralled to the back of the shops to make way for the Spring/Summer and Christmas party ranges.
But soon the windows and shelves will be covered with all things necessary for the festive season. Retailers and their landlords rely on the lead-up to Christmas to generate a significant proportion of sales for the year. That cuts across food, alcohol, and apparel, to decorations and trees, tableware/glassware, napery and of course, gifts.
While most of the shops are currently holding mid season sales, they will now look to offering the recommended retail price. That is where the higher margins can be generated.
The lower Australian dollar is also a double-edged sword for retailers. Imports are more expensive, particularly for electronics, but it is also proving a deterrent for overseas travel, leaving more people at home scouring the shops.
So get ready, as it is starting to feel a lot like Christmas.
